habitat_description:
This species of salamander has been recently been described and are only known from 13 localities in the southern foothills of the San Gabriel and San Bernardino mountains of southern California (Wake 1996; Goodman et al. 1998).  The distribution is described as discontinuous through public lands that are under the administration of the Los Angeles and San Bernardino National Forests (Lannoo 2005). Egg deposition sites are presumed to involve talus piles (Lannoo 2005). 
Adult habitat includes bark, downed branches, ferns, under rotting logs, talus accumulations, and rocks (Wake 1996; Goodman et al. 1998). The San Gabriel Mountains contain talus slopes, various pines, white fir, big-cone spruce, incense cedar, and canyon live oak (Wake 1996). But, other populations have been reported in drier and more exposed areas with chaparral communities.

Mixed conifer forest characterized by various species of pines, big-cone spruce, white fir, canyon live oak, incense cedar, while cover is less abundant in the chaparral habitat (Green et al. 2013).
